intro: Echidnopsis jacksonii, commonly known as Jackson's ghost flower, is a rare and striking member of the Aizoaceae family, native to the arid regions of South Africa. It is characterized by its unique, tubular flowers that resemble ghostly apparitions, hence its common name. The plant typically grows from a compact, succulent base, with leaves that are fleshy and often covered in fine hairs. It thrives in well-drained soils and requires minimal water, making it well-suited to dry, rocky habitats. Due to its rarity and specific habitat requirements, it is often cultivated by enthusiasts who appreciate its unusual appearance and ecological significance.
